rename.to: [BUG] multiple tests related to `FRESH` fail on win and python 3.8.5

rename.from: [BUG] multiple tests related to `FRESH` fail on win and python 3.8.5
rename.to: [BUG] multiple tests related to `FRESH` fail on win and python 3.8.5 and 3.7.9

body:
Might be related to this message (extracted from CI):

```bash
tsfresh 0.19.0 requires statsmodels>=0.13, but you'll have statsmodels 0.12.1 which is incompatible.
```

After bumping `statsmodels` to `>=0.13` I now have the same tests failing on all platforms. It seems that by fixing a dependency conflict I found some more failing tests.  @MatthewMiddlehurst I saw your name in the `sktime/classification/feature_based/_tsfresh_classifier.py` module, would you be able to help with this?

issue.title: CI/CD refactor and switch to github actions

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs

- Fixes #1482 
- Fixes #1728 
- Fixes #1803
- Fixes #1832

See also #1150 
Refactoring of github actions workflows started in #1321 

Currently blocked by: 
- [x] #1644
- [x] #1661
- [x] #1662 
- [x] #1792
- [x] #1747
- [x] #1783
- [x] #1803
- [x] update installation instructions in [docs/source/installation.rst](docs/source/installation.rst)


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This is a rather substantial effort involving changes to how `sktime` is build and distributed. The main changes are:

-  Add [pyproject.toml](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/build-system/pyproject-toml/) (see [PEP 621](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0621/) and [PEP 633](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0633/)]. The intention behind is to collect all package matadata and dependencies in one place.
- Add sets of optional dependencies:
    - `all_extras` all "soft" dependencies
    - `dev` packages useful for development and testing
    - `binder` packages required for binder and running notebook examples
    - `docs` packages required to build the documentation
- Add section to build time dependencies.
- Refactor existing CI/CD pipelines to use the new build configuration.
- Introduced a new CI/CD pipelines for running tests across win, mac, linux and py37, py38, py39 with github actions.
- Removed the obsolete requirements files.
- Include wheels build for macosx on arm64.

**Removed**

- ❌ Drop support for python3.6
- ❌ Drop appveyor and azure pipelines

**High level diagram for the CI/CD workflows**

![sktime-cicd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8989838/149678967-309054eb-e91e-4988-a6cf-321de0108eb8.png)


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

It does not introduce any new runtime/install dependencies but it could introduce an optional development depencency/build system such as [poetry](https://python-poetry.org/) to simplify development/build/distribution.

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

This PR introduces changed to the CI/CD pipelines that would hopefully allow to drop ``appveyor`` and ``azure pipelines`` in favor of ``github actions`` which would simplify the current build and maintenance process.

#### Any other comments?


#### PR checklist

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

rename.from: [BUG] multiple tests related to `FRESH` fail on win and python 3.8.5 and 3.7.9
rename.to: [BUG] multiple tests related to `FRESH` fail on all platforms and python versions

body:
These tests compare the current outputs from the classifier to a set of saved results. Is there any good reason why this would change the results? If so, we can just update the reference results.

I assume the TSFresh transform results are different as well? How much do they change from the previous version?

Thanks for the input @MatthewMiddlehurst. 

> Is there any good reason why this would change the results?

The thing that I can say for sure is that there was a dependency conflict since tsfresh has `statsmodels>=0.13` however sktime has essentially `statsmodels==0.12.1` which is a conflict that pip is apparently happy to ignore. Once I bumped `statsmodels>=0.13` the fresh related tests failed. I haven't investigated further at this point.

> I assume the TSFresh transform results are different as well? How much do they change from the previous version?

That is possible although I haven't seen any other fresh related tests failing. 

Let me know if you have the appetite to tackle this, otherwise I will simply update the expected values for tests.

I can try taking a look at some point if necessary. This seems like an issue with the transformer having different results to previous versions I would guess, though. 

Given TSFresh requires `statsmodels>=0.13` maybe the new ones are the correct values? I would normally say that the tests are passing doesn't mean it is working correctly, but in this case I would just trust TSFresh developers and update the expected values to the new results.

It's not the best currently, but there is a space setup in `contrib/_classification_test_reproduction.py` to help with updating the expected results.

Thanks for the offer to look into this. This is currently blocking #1620 which I was planning to get done within the next week, provided that I won't find any more surprises on the way. Let me know if you would be able to have look within that timeline otherwise I can fix this as mentioned above.
I've updated the expected values for the tests after bumping the dependency so this can be closes after #1620. I'll add a statement to the PR description to close this automatically.
